prompt.preamble:
We are testing a system for understanding people's interest in reading different kinds of online articles.
For example, you might be interested in articles about some topics, but not about others.
prompt.task_description: your preferences of what kinds of online articles you would like to read
prompt.final: In the final part of the study, you will give feedback on a test set of article headline and descriptions, which will enable us to see how well a chatbot reading your responses has learned what you like and dislike.
prompt.evaluation: Please indicate whether you would like to read the following articles: "yes" if you would, "no" if you would not.

conversation_history.message: What types of online communities or forums do you participate in, and what topics do you typically engage with or read about in these spaces?
Normally I engage on facebook, reddit and in discord servers.
What types of articles or blog posts do you usually find yourself reading outside of these online communities, and what draws you to those specific topics?
Anything regarding human rights, various crafting mediums and herbalism. Those are my big three.
Can you share more about any podcasts, documentaries, or books you enjoy that relate to your interests, and how these mediums further enhance your understanding or enjoyment of these topics?

Reading about herbalism increases my awareness of the plants and herbs available to reat mild ailments. Which has come in handy when pharmaceuticals do not work for me. I specifically like the Encyclopedia of Magical Herbs.

Can you tell me about any specific projects or initiatives you've undertaken related to your interests in human rights, crafting, or herbalism, and how these experiences have influenced your online reading choices?

Regarding crafting, I'm currently working on a blanket for the baby I am expecting. I am looming it, which is difficult at times. As far as human rights, I actively stay on top of the legislature coming out that is attacking the livlihood of the gay community as I am a member of it.

Can you share any online resources, websites, or influencers you follow that provide you with new insights or perspectives on human rights, crafting, or herbalism, and how do these sources influence your understanding or approach to these topics?

For crafting, I find that pinterest.com has a wide variety of project ideas. For human rights, it's hit or miss based on the website as all have personal biases and it's up to us as media consumers to decide where to read. I find myself trusting peer sources more than big media.

Can you tell me about any events, workshops, or meetups you've attended related to your interests in human rights, crafting, or herbalism, and how these experiences have shaped your perspective or approach to these topics?
Unfortunately being pregnant I have not been able to attend any meetups, with the exception of the local pride fest which was a huge event and so much fun while I was able to be there.

Can you share any specific online articles or discussions that have significantly impacted your views or understanding on human rights, crafting, or herbalism, and how did these pieces of information influence your actions or decisions related to these interests?
From the New York Times, this is a great article regarding herbalism:https://www.nytimes.com/2020/11/12/t-magazine/plants-medicine-doctrine-of-signatures.html

Can you tell me about any specific online communities or forums dedicated to human rights, crafting, or herbalism that you've found particularly helpful or enlightening, and how these communities have influenced your understanding or approach to these topics?

evaluation_results.sample:
Website Name: New York Times
Title: In Norway, the Electric Vehicle Future Has Already Arrived
Description: About 80 percent of new cars sold in Norway are battery-powered. As a result, the air is cleaner, the streets are quieter and the grid hasn’t collapsed. But problems with unreliable chargers persist.
evaluation_results.label: yes

query_prompt.content:
Your task is to learn what topics a user is interested in reading online article about. People's interests are broad, so you should seek to understand their interests across many topics; in other words, go for breadth rather than depth. Do not assume a user has given a complete answer to any question, so make sure to keep probing different types of interests.

Previous questions:
- [Q] -> [A]

Generate the most informative open-ended question that, when answered, will reveal the most about the desired behavior beyond what has already been queried for above. Make sure your question addresses different aspects of the user's interests than the questions that have already been asked. At the same time however, the question should be bite-sized, and not ask for too much at once. Generate the open-ended question and nothing else:
